Could this be the lady in the photo?

PIERCE, Annie (Nancy) (née O'Brien) (Wexford) - May 29, 2010 (peacefully) at the Beacon Hospital, following a short illness at home; beloved wife of the late Philip B. Pierce, loving mother of Pamela, Jacinta and Philip; sadly missed by her sister Monnie Keane, her grandchildren Caroline and Stuart, son-in-law Terry, relatives and friends. Regretted by her nurse Anne Boucher and her carers after many loving and dedicated years of care in her own home. Funeral today (Wednesday) after 10 o'clock Mass in the Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Succour, Foxrock to Crosstown Cemetery, Wexford.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: 'When I was a boy Pierces Foundry ran up all the way to Avenue Flandres and they used to test the ploughs in the fields outside my house.' In fact Avenue de Flandres, Casa Rio and Alvina Brook were all named by Philip B Pierce, a descendant of Pierce's founder Philip Pierce, to remind him of foreign fields he had visited, and Philip Pierce himself designed the unique conservatory in Castlebridge, which unlike the foundry itself is still standing, although it's badly in need of some TLC and slowly rusting away. Pierces began life at its Distillery Road premises in 1839 and by 1900, 600 people worked there. There were few people in Wexford town who over the years didn't have some connection with the company, a brother, son or father working there. When Pierces closed almost four years ago, it was the last gasp of a dying industry. www.independent.ie/regionals/wexfordpeople/news/part-and-...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From the excellent National Inventory of Architectural Heritage site:
A picturesque memorial folly erected in commemoration of James Pierce (1813-68), founder (1839) of the Pierce Ironworks Foundry (or Mill Road Iron Works or Folly Mills Iron Works and Agricultural Machinery and Implement Factory) in Distillery Road, Wexford Town (see 15505068 - 69) recalling the contemporary (1857) round tower erected at Ferrycarrig in honour of the soldiers lost in the Crimean War (1854-6) (see NIAH Wexford County Survey 2007). Having been well maintained, the memorial contributes dramatically to the group and setting values of the Park House (Ballyboggan House) estate.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Long but worth a read - I think Wexford Town continues to enjoy a long-standing, albeit much depleted industrial heritage with a number of substantial warehouses once supporting the local agricultural economy through the gathering of grain for the purpose of brewing, milling into flour for export, and so on. Complementing this legacy, the town once boasted a large manufacturing industry with activity concentrated at either end of the town: the Selskar Iron Works (established 1897) in the north of the town with the Star Ironworks (opened 1882) off Trinity Street and the Folly Mills Iron Works and Agricultural Machinery and Implement Factory, or Pierce Ironworks Foundry, at the meeting of Distillery Road with Mill Road in the south of the town. Having been established in 1839 by James Pierce (1813-68), the Pierce Ironworks Foundry was subsequently developed by the Pierce brothers Philip (1850-95), Martin (d. 1907) and John (d. 1926) to such an extent that at one time the complex represented the largest engineering or agricultural machinery manufacturer in the country with offices located in Paris and Buenos Aires. However, commercial success was interrupted in August 1911 during the infamous "Lock-Out" when the Pierces sought to prevent workers from joining the Irish Transport and General Workers Union (ITGWU): soon all of the foundries in the town had followed suit leading to a series of pickets and protests which were not resolved until February of the following year. Although the last vestiges of the complex (between 1868-1903) have recently (2006-7) been cleared to make way for the redevelopment of the site, the legacy of the foundry prevails in the output of, and the numerous off-shoot developments sponsored by the Pierces in the late nineteenth and early to mid twentieth centuries. For instance, the cast-iron railings (between 1862-80) embellishing the perimeter of the "twin churches" were supplied and maintained for one hundred years by the company. Meanwhile, a housing scheme was established at Avenue de Flandres (1939), Mulgannon Road, for senior managers with a later scheme (1947) at Casa Rio, Distillery Road, intended for middle management: a contemporary scheme at Alvina Brook (1946) similarly bears a named derived from or inspired by the location of the Pierce offices around the globe. A comparatively short-lived venture, the Pierce Plough Foundry or Pierce Bicycle Works, operated between 1903-41 on the site of the earlier Bishop.s Water Distillery complex (opened 1827): the entrance on to the grounds survives to the present day in the form of a commanding Classical-style gate screen. Manifesting, in physical form, the success of the foundry and the resulting financial rewards, the Pierce family seat, Park House (c.1750), originally Ballyboggan House, Ballyboggan in the north of the town forms the centrepiece of a middle-size suburban estate embellished with artefacts salvaged from the Castleboro House estate (relocated between 1923-32), further structures (1868 and 1907) commemorating various members of the family, and, in a reflection of the paranoia stemming from "The Emergency" (1939-45), a mass-concrete air raid shelter (1940). View Buildings www.buildingsofireland.ie/niah/highlights.jsp?county=WX&a...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: From revpatrickcomerford.blogspot.ie/2010/10/three-more-pugin-... Re: Saint Mary’s Church, Tagoat Almost half a century passed before the church was consecrated on 12 September 1899. Since then, this Pugin church has undergone many alterations, and many parts of the interior were completely stripped of any original decoration by Pugin. From 1946 until the early 1950s, extensive renovations were carried out through the generosity of Philip Pierce, a parishioner and a member of the family associated with a famous foundry in Wexford.

If I  am correct and the death notice above is correct it would suggest that she lived to the ripe old age of 92 to 97.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Note; Maura Winter (nee Keane) is shown below as a Niece of Philip B. In the death notice for Annie, she is sadly missed by her sister Monnie Keane. So the death notice is probably correct. ------------------------------------------------------------ Pierce's clock a sign of the times Accepting the clock on Tesco's behalf, Ronan Doyle, the Oulart-born General Manager of the new supermarket, said he was proud as a Wexford man to have the opportunity to honour the history of Pierce Engineering. Among those at the handover, which took place at White's Hotel, were descendents of former Pierce founders and employees, including Maura Winter (nee Keane), the niece of the late Philip B. Pierce, representing the Pierce family. Trades unionists who were there included Ger Murphy, who represented the workers for more than 30 years. www.independent.ie/regionals/wexfordpeople/news/pierces-c...
